label.intro:
Agroecological research requires a holistic approach which takes into account the diversity and variability of contexts, including peopleâ€™s values and motivations, and the multitude of dimensions that coexist at the same time. These concepts, individually and together, exist within systems. We use systems thinking to understand the relationships between things; systems analysis explores how system components interact and influence each other.

Traditional research considers an isolated component of a system and aims to optimise this. What is efficient for one component may however be harmful for another component, and so systems thinking requires taking this complexity seriously. 

Agricultural food systems exist at many levels and are multifunctional, transdisciplinary, dynamic, and influenced by human culture. These systems are worthy of study!
